The chunk is situated within a section of the document discussing storage and typesetting conventions for matrices. It explains how different terms like "row-major" and "column-major" relate to both storage order and typesetting format, highlighting their potential confusion due to independence between these aspects. This context is part of a broader discussion on matrix handling in Panda, OpenGL, and DirectX, focusing on storage order and manual notation differences.

The Terms "Column Major" and "Row Major"

The term "row-major" means "the first four coefficients that you store, are also the first row when you typeset." So the four possibilities break down like this:

Store derivatives of xo first, typeset in row-vector-compatible notation (COLUMN MAJOR)

Store derivatives of xo first, typeset in column-vector-compatible notation (ROW MAJOR)

Store derivatives wrt xi first, typeset in row-vector-compatible notation (ROW MAJOR)

Store derivatives wrt xi first, typeset in column-vector-compatible notation (COLUMN MAJOR)
